block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Kosovo Albanians See Vote as Proof of Self-Rule Kosovo Albanians swarmed around polling stations in cheerful moods to take part in municipal elections, the first poll of any sort they have had for eight years and the first experienced away from Communist or Serbian police authorities.
INTERNATIONAL

Kosovo Albanians See Vote as Proof of Self-Rule Kosovo Albanians swarmed around polling stations in cheerful moods to take part in municipal elections, the first poll of any sort they have had for eight years and the first experienced away from Communist or Serbian police authorities.

Victory for Protestant Leader David Trimble, head of the Ulster Unionists, Northern Ireland's largest Protestant party, narrowly held on to his leadership in a vote of confidence, but only after adopting a far harder line toward Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army.

F.B.I. Blast Inquiry Hindered Yemen's government has refused to allow the F.B.I. to attend interviews with suspects about the suicide bombing that killed 17 American sailors on the destroyer Cole, raising fears that evidence could be delayed, misunderstood, or suppressed.

Roiling Tensions in Mideast The emotional funerals of four Palestinians who were shot dead on Friday proved the flashpoint for renewed clashes in the West Bank and Gaza, leaving at least 29 Palestinians injured in Gaza, including a 14-year-old boy who was shot in the head.
NATIONAL

Drive Under Way to Raise Turnout of Black Voters Democrats and civil rights organizations have begun a sweeping effort to increase the turnout of black voters. In several close states, Vice President Al Gore's chances may hinge on the effort's effectiveness.
The candidacy of Gov. George W. Bush came into being partly on its own several years ago, at first surprising even Mr. Bush.
Neither campaign seems sure whether Ohio is still a swing state, so strategies and spending are fluctuating widely.
Pet Projects in Congress Democratic lawmakers hold their own with Republicans when it comes to securing money for pet projects back home.
Diet Fraud on the Rise A surging demand for a weight loss ''silver bullet'' has fueled a rapid rise in fraudulent advertising.
Eagle Hunt May Be Allowed Hopi Indians may be allowed to collect baby eagles at a national monument for use in a rite in which the birds are killed.
Break-In at Microsoft Microsoft said the break-in of its network occurred over a few days and not several weeks.
NEW YORK/REGION

Mrs. Clinton Accuses Lazio Of Exploiting Terrorist Attack Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Rick A. Lazio clashed over an attempt by the New York Republican Party to link Mrs. Clinton to the terrorist attack on a United States destroyer in Yemen earlier this month. Mrs. Clinton denounced the tactic as a ''new low'' in the campaign, but Mr. Lazio said he would not apologize for it.

Nassau G.O.P. Sheds Colors Republican candidates have dropped the electric blue and orange that had come to symbolize both Nassau County and its reigning party. The new colors are soothing pastels and earth tones, a switch that is not inconsequential; it is a visible sign of their rush to abandon the county's once vaunted Republican machine.
OBITUARIES

William T. Hurtz A founder of the trendsetting United Productions of America animation studio, he was 81. The animator's career stretched from Walt Disney in the 1930's to ''Rugrats'' in the 1990's, with stops in between for Mr. Magoo, George of the Jungle and Cap'n Crunch.

43 Cong. Vote
